titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Light winds and fair. The weather at length has assumed a moderate temperature, and is become almost fair. This afternoon for the first time for several days we saw a brig. Steering apparently towards Europe— Distance at noon 124 miles— Lat: 48:6. Long 28.

2. The light and favourable winds continue— I am reading Marmontel’s Nouveaux Contes Moraux, after having finish’d La Harpe.— The weather begins to be warm. This was the finest day we have had since we embark’d— Distance 133 miles— Lat: 46:56. Long: 29.50.
3. The winds are still fair, and the weather fine. Towards night it became almost calm. Our Latitude was 45:37. Longitude about 33.
4. Clear weather and a fresh breeze the whole day; we saw two vessels steering the same course with ourselves— Overtook and ran them out of sight— Lat: 44:33. Long: 36.
5. The wind blows almost a gale, but continues to be favourable— We saw a vessel at a distance. Lat: 43:32. Long: 40. Distance run 180 miles.
6. Foggy weather; brisk and variable winds; with frequent squalls. Towards evening it clear’d away fair— Saw a brig, steering towards Newfoundland. Lat 43:29: Long: 43. Distance 130 miles.
7. Weather much the same as yesterday— This afternoon we overtook and spoke with the ship Harriet of Baltimore bound from London to Baltimore, out eighteen days. Lat: 42:17. Long: 46. Dist: 184.

8. Our fair winds which have lasted us just a fortnight, and in that time brought us more than two thousand miles upon our way have at length forsaken us and left us this day in a calm. Our Lat: is 41:14, our Long: 49. Distance 162 miles. Mrs: A. very ill.

9. Calm the greatest part of the day. Warm and sultry weather— We have this day a new moon. Towards evening a breeze of wind, quite ahead— Lat: 40:37. Long: 49:30. Dist: about 50 miles. I read Garve’s translation of Cicero’s offices, with his philosophical commentary. Though unable to give the application of mind to it which it deserves I read it with much pleasure, and I hope with some profit.— Mrs: A. better.

10. Spoke early this morning with a schooner from Halifax, out sixteen days, and bound to Madeira. Saw two other vessels in the course of the day— Had a fresh breeze and a great swell, with the wind a-head— Lat: 40:41. Long: 50. distance not more than 50 miles again.

11. Calm weather, the greatest part of the day, with contrary winds. In the evening heavy showers; and variable winds— I have finish’d reading La Fontaine’s fables. Lat: 40:37: Long: 50:30. Distance scarcely any thing.

12. In the night the wind blew very fresh, and it has continued with a great swell all this day; but though somewhat variable it has only been between the points absolutely adverse to us.— The weather too has become warm and sultry to a degree that allows little comfort— Lat: 40:4. Long: 51. Distance nothing.

13. Our succession of calms and contrary winds continues without any other variation— The weather too still grows warmer, and the principal part of our little progress is to the Southward. Lat: 39:42. Long: 51:30.

14. A calm day, with fair weather and excessive heat. we had however in the night a breeze which allowed us to make more way to the Southward than we have done for some days. Lat: 38:19. Long 51:50. c I finish’d reading the new moral tales of Marmontel; which have given me so much pleasure that I regret coming to the end of them.

15. Finished reading Garve’s remarks and dissertation upon Cicero’s Offices— I have seldom read a book with more satisfaction: The last treatise however containing the author’s system of political morality, pleases me less than any other part of the work. It is founded too much upon Prussian maxims of State; and bends rather too much to the practice of Frederic the great— I began Ségur’s reign of Frederic William 2. We still have contrary winds— Lat: 38:52. Long: 52 1/2— Saw a ship this afternoon.

16. The wind has been quite fresh and so far to the southward that our Lat: is 39:59. but we can go very little to the westward— Long: 53, by the Captain’s Chronometer or Time piece; made by Arnold, and said to be an improvement of Harrison’s.

17. The moon quarter’d this morning at about 2 o’clock; all the fore part of the day we had brisk winds and successive squalls from the S.W.— At 4 in the afternoon while it blew very hard, the wind shifted instantaneously from S.W. to N.E.—it abated gradually in the course of the evening but left a very heavy swell all night— I spent part of it upon deck, being unable to sleep.— 39:32. & 53 1/2.

18. Had a fair and light wind the whole day; the first time these ten days— This evening the Sun set clear which is the promise of an easterly wind.— The weather beautiful, and the air cool and pleasant— We saw a schooner this afternoon.— Finish’d reading Ségur’s reign of Frederic William 2.— A work of very little merit; with great professions of impartiality and nothing of it. Our Lat: is 39.:56. and our Longitude about 54.

19. The fair wind deserted us in the night, and the promise of the setting Sun was deceptive. We had all day strong westerly winds, and heavy squalls, increasing in violence untill Sunset this evening. The wind then changed and abated— But the swell continued so heavy that the ship pitched more than she has done before upon the voyage— Heavy thunder clouds with continual lightening all round the horizon— Mrs: A— excessively alarmed, and very ill— Lat: 38:42— Long 56:12. I began to read Malone’s life of Dryden.
20. Weather calm the greatest part of the day; but with a very heavy swell from the westward, which hove the ship a-stern for several hours— Mrs: A. extremely ill, all day— Lat: 38:4— Long: 56:30.

21. Mrs: A— continues very ill—though rather better than yesterday.— Brisk and contrary wind, with frequent squalls and a heavy swell racking the ship. In the morning we had a slight thunder-gust. I have been about these Latitudes before in the month of July; and for a month together had such weather and winds as we now suffer. Lat: 38:5. Long: about 57. Finish’d reading Malone’s life of Dryden, and began the letters— Malone’s biographical talents chiefly consist in compilation.
22. We had warm light winds the former part of the day and in the afternoon frequent squalls, from the West and Southwest.— Long: 36:56— Long: 57:30.
23. Frequent squalls all night, and at 4 this morning a very violent one. The weather fair and mild through the day—but the wind freshened very much at night— Lat: 38:8. Long: 59.

24. The moon at full— It blew quite a gale of wind early this morning— Before noon it very suddenly became calm— Afterwards A wind to the northward; but almost calm. We saw three vessels in the afternoon. Lat: without observation about 40— Long: 59:30.

25. Fine weather and wind though light in the forenoon— At noon we spoke with an English brig from Norfolk in Virginia, bound to London, out 6 days— Her long: 62:35. In the afternoon our wind drew a-head again and blew almost a gale— Three other vessels pass’d us in the evening. Lat: 39:27. Long: 61.

26. The gale continued until 9 this morning. Sea very heavy. Then it cleared away with a small thunder-gust, and the rest of the day we had a fair wind, but so light as scarcely to make us stem the great swell heading us.— Saw a ship afternoon, steering our course— Think her the Harriet, whom we spoke with before. Lat: unobserved, 41— Long: 63:22.
27. The wind has continued fair but very light— Weather fine— The ship we saw yesterday continues to steer our course, and keeps at about the same distance from us. Lat: 39:12. Long: 65:30.

28. A calm night, and almost calm all this day— Our companion still attends us. The sun has set clear the four last nights— It gives us pleasant weather but no winds. At night our wind drew a head again. The west and southwest breezes are inflexible at this season. Lat: 38:40. Long: 66:30.
29. Continuance of fair weather, and of winds almost a-head. We saw a ship a brig and a schooner in the course of the day. Lat: 38:50. Long: 67:56.

30. The wind this morning came round to the Northward and died away. Calm all the rest of it. The ship which has followed us these three days, steered more to the Southward and left us. Saw a sloop this afternoon— I finish’d reading Malone’s Edition of Dryden’s prose. I cannot so much admire it, as its reputation requires. It has given me some entertainment, but I think very little instruction— Lat: 39:21— Long: 69.

31. With the wind at Southwest this was a very fine day. We saw a ship brig and sloop in the course of it. Lat: 38:57.— Long: by the Captain’s time-piece 71:11.— But the great change in the colour of the water, the smoothness of the sea, and the land-birds we saw indicating the proximity of the land we sounded this evening at 8, and found bottom at 14 fathoms— We are therefore not more than that number of leagues from the shore; that is our Longitude must be about 74. and the Captain’s time-piece or his calculations from it erroneous about 10 minutes. I began reading Sir Joshua Reynolds’s works.

Day. The same as the last month. I have read Marmontel’s new moral tales—La Fontaine’s fables, Garve’s work upon Cicero’s offices, Segur’s reign of Frederic William 2. and Malone’s Dryden. But I have done nothing else but read, and that to little purpose.— The time has been somewhat tedious, but is now I hope, nearly at an end.
